medical_history.chief_complaint: Severe polyhydramnios and prematurity in pregnancies with male offspring.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Polyhydramnios was recognized early in pregnancy, at 19 to 20 weeks of gestation. The motherâ€™s first pregnancy resulted in preterm delivery of a stillborn male at 22 weeks, while subsequent pregnancies led to severe polyhydramnios diagnosed at 19 weeks, resulting in a preterm male infant born at 27 weeks. Symptoms greatly intensified with progressive polyuria observed immediately after birth in the living infants, normalizing in 3 to 4 weeks.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The family had three pregnancies with male offspring complicated by severe polyhydramnios. Previous pregnancies with female fetuses were uneventful. In infants, neonatal polyuria lasted from 3 days to 6 weeks and was associated with severe hypercalciuria causing medullary nephrocalcinosis.
medical_history.family_history: In one family, the first son suffered from acute, early-onset severe polyhydramnios, while two subsequent pregnancies with female fetuses were normal.
